Award.AwardTitle: Endoscopic STED Nanoscopy with Optical FIber Vortices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to (1) demonstrate a compact and potentially cost effective fiber device that will be a drop-in replacement for the complex optics that are susceptible to thermal and environmental drifts in today's nanoscale microscopes operating on the principle of stimulated emission and spatial depletion; and (2) design a next generation fiber capable of incorporating all optical components of the aforementioned bulk microscope to realize endoscopic implementations of nanoscale imaging systems.

The intellectual merit of this program is the realization that optical fibers can be specially designed to support orbital angular momentum carrying vortex beams, which lead to unprecedented multicolor control of the optical beam shape that exits the fiber and impinges on a sample. This development, combined with microscopy principles enabling super-resolution with complex beams, would lead to the first compact, alignment-free all-fiber imaging system capable of 20-50 nm resolution.

The broader impacts of this program are twofold: (1) Developing minimally-invasive technologies that can image, at the nanoscale, cellular, subcellular, molecular, and genetic processes in living organisms, which would significantly advance our understanding of human pathobiology; (2) Optical vortices form one of the most visually appealing beam patterns, resembling spirals whose physics is related to tornado-formation, and their manipulation with fibers enables developing curricula for a diverse array of students ranging from high-schools to graduate-schools, which would help attract more US talent to the disciplines of science, engineering and mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stimulated Emission Depletion (STED) microscopy is an exciting technique for imaging objects that are much smaller than the wavelength of light, which are otherwise not resolvable. The technique's successes were recognized with an award of the Nobel prize to its inventor. The utility of this microscopy technique notwithstanding, it requires a set of very finely aligned complex beams. Work in this project had aimed to, and has successfully developed the first optical fiber-based microscope that can perform STED microscopy. The outcome of this study shook a long-standing assumption that complex beams cannot be stably transmitted in optical fibers. By disproving that over the course of this project, the door has been opened to not only performing STED microscopy with optical fibers, but performing a multitude of spatially complex beam illumination and detection with fiber in applications that require it. The obvious benefit of utilizing an optical fiber for such applications is the ability to flexibly route or otherwise deploy with ease, a complex microscope. Perhaps more intriguingly, a fiber based microscope would facilitate super-resolution imaging in freely moving animals for the first time. 

The broader aims of this project are related to the introduction of fiber optics in general, and complex beams and their applications, specifically. Over the course of this project, several high-school modules were shown across Boston area high schools showcasing such optical fibers' unique capabilities to enhance the bandwidth of tomorrow's internet highways. In addition, this project provided the means to train 3 PhD students, including one female, 5 undergraduate students, including one female, one high-school summer intern, and one female postdoctoral researcher.
